article.title: Cosmological perturbations and stability of nonsingular cosmologies with limiting curvature

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the curves in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The evolution of the scale factor in the inflationary and genesis scenarios.
The behavior of the curvature invariants as a function of the scalar fields.
The Hubble parameter as a function of the scalar fields in the inflationary scenario.
The evolution of the energy density and pressure in the inflationary scenario.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the green curve in Figure 2 represent?
choices: A background trajectory where the universe starts in a Minkowski spacetime and ends in a de Sitter spacetime.
A background trajectory where the universe starts and ends in a Minkowski spacetime.
A background trajectory where the universe starts in a de Sitter spacetime and ends in a Minkowski spacetime.
A background trajectory where the universe remains in a de Sitter spacetime throughout its evolution.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which type of cosmological scenario does Figure 3 illustrate?
choices: An inflationary scenario where the universe starts in an asymptotically de Sitter spacetime.
A genesis scenario where the universe starts in an asymptotically Minkowski spacetime.
A bouncing scenario where the universe contracts and then expands.
A cyclic scenario where the universe undergoes repeated cycles of expansion and contraction.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main advantage of using the new curvature-invariant function (I_1) defined in equations (66) & (70)?
choices: It simplifies the background equations of motion, making them easier to solve.
It leads to a more stable theory, avoiding ghost instabilities even around anisotropic backgrounds.
It allows for the inclusion of matter sources without spoiling the nonsingular nature of the cosmology.
It provides a natural mechanism for reheating in both the inflationary and genesis scenarios.
